message: feel free to stop by if you aren't sure what you're doing by sunday night
Looking for something I can sprint on, need something that will tolerate a noob and uses mercurial, preferably something sciency, djangoish or geospatial
hack shapely
though there's no one actually developing shapely here :)
justin bronn was here, so you could in theory find him and get to sprint on geodjango with him
The sprint leaders will all get up tomorrow and talk about their projects
Help with Twiggy, a Pythonic Logger: http://twiggy.wearpants.org/
great for new sprinters
Both good ideas and twiggy is using mercurial
we're doing an open gov't sprint for the 3rd year, it is always a decent project for beginners as there are a lot of open gov projects under our banner (we're sprinting on at least two)

Twisted needs new contributors really badly, so we will be extra nice to newcomers :).  We also need people who will do things like update the web site and write documentation for the tools (as opposed to the library), so non-technical people would also be welcome.

look at the http://bugs.python.org/ for issues flagged 'easy' (this query: http://goo.gl/WsDka). Want to get involved in cpython itself? see any that peak your interest? if so the python core dev. sprint would love sprinters for this!
Come sprint on Mercurial!
Come to gunicorn sprint http://gunicorn-pycon2011.couch.it/ :)
Come and sprint on http://djangopackages.com and help us launch http://pythonpackages.com
We'd love to have you with allura (http://sf.net/p/allura)
So many options...

@glyph - I'm diving to twisted for a new project and imagine I will be spending quite a bit of time with the documentation. Is there a hitlist of current issues with the docs or some simple tools that would be useful? Where would you recommend I start beyond scrubbing though some bugs and reading the docs?
@magicbeef By "diving to twisted", do you mean you are looking to find some work to do to contribute to Twisted?

@glyph Yes. "Diving into twisted" as in I have I project that requires me to learn how to use twisted and wanted to know what  I could do to contribute  while learning and reading the docs which I am doing anyway. Is there any low hanging fruit on your radar documentation wise that you think someone new to the project (but not new to python) could tackle. I'm happy to help out and get involved in any way I can. I went through the bugs marked "Easy" but I am not even ready for any of those yet. For now I'll lurk in the IRC channel...

@magicbeef Sorry I haven't been able to be too responsive, in-person interactions are kind of taking priority at the moment :).  We try to keep http://bit.ly/easy-twisted-tickets up to date with simple stuff for newcomers to pick up
but you can look in the tracker for 'documentation' keywords
we're on the verge of a gigantic documentation migration ... thing, which should happen soon
